dc.title: Alice and the Caterpillar
dc.abstract: Hudson (1909-1935) was a painter and poster artist who illustrated editions both of Alice and of J.M. Barrie's Peter Pan and Wendy.  Her illustration of Alice are among the more well-known extant.  Here Hudson depicts the meeting between Alice and the hookah-smoking Caterpillar, an encounter particularly maddening for Alice because of the Caterpillar's rude questions and gnomic utterances.
dc.creator: Gwynedd M. Hudson
dc.citation: Lewis Carroll. Alice's Adventures in Wonderland (Centenary Edition). Hodder & Stroughton, 1932
dc.rights: A copyright review process in August 2018 has determined that this particular item, published in the UK, is in the public domain since the illustrator died more than 70 years ago.
dc.relation.ispartofseries: "Who in the world am I? Ah, that's the great puzzle!": The Faces of Alice in Wonderland

dc.title: Alice and the mushroom
dc.abstract: Henderson's Alice is very much a girl of her time, wearing a flapper dress, with her hair cut in a fashionable bob.  She is eating a bit of mushroom, which will go on to make her neck longer, until she is so tall that she can no longer see her hands.
dc.creator: Hume Henderson
dc.citation: Lewis Carroll. Alice's Adventures in Wonderland. Readers Library, 1932
dc.rights: A copyright review process in August 2018 has determined that this particular item is in copyright, but the rights holder is unclear or unresponsive. dc.title: Alice with a Flamingo
dc.abstract: The illustrations by Groves-Reines are remarkably similar in style to the classic illustrations by Sir John Tenniel.  Likewise, this story is written remarkably like the original Alice in Wonderland, but with references to Guinness beer throughout.  Here, we see Alice and the Duchess discussing a glass of Guinness that is nearly as tall as they are.
dc.creator: Ralph Gore Antony Groves-Raines
dc.citation: Lewis Carroll. Alice Aforethought. Arthur Guinness, Sons & Co., 1938

dc.abstract: The illustrations by Groves-Reines are remarkably similar in style to the classic illustrations by Sir John Tenniel. dc.title: Alice and the animals listening to the Mouse's story
dc.abstract: This edition of Alice, in Swahili, is the first version translated into a native African language.  The illustrator has copied the original Tenniel illustrations but has made all the human characters (except, notably, the King and Queen of Hearts) African.  Alice is dressed in a white wrap of khanga cloth, and the Hatter wears a fez rather than the traditional English top hat.
dc.creator: Unidentified
dc.citation: Lewis Carroll. Elisi Katika Nchi Ya Ajabu. Sheldon Press, 1940
dc.rights: A copyright review process in August 2018 has revealed that this particular item has been determined to be in the public domain by the Internet Archive.  See:  https://archive.org/details/elisikatikanchiy00carrrich

dc.title: Wool and Water
dc.abstract: In this illustration, Alice has just passed from the Fifth Square to the Sixth.  The White Queen has transformed into a shopkeeping sheep, and in moments the shop has become a boat floating down a river.  Ralph Steadman is an English illustrator and political and social caricaturist, best known for his longtime atistic collaboration with Hunter S. Thompson.
dc.creator: Ralph Steadman
dc.citation: Lewis Carroll. Alice, Lewis Carroll's Through the Looking Glass and What Alice Found There (Illustrated by Ralph Steadman). C.N. Potter, 1973
dc.rights: A copyright review process in August 2018 has determined that this particular illustration is still in copyright, held by the illustrator, Ralph Steadman (©1973), who graciously shared permission for Texas A&M University Libraries to display this image in this online exhibit. dc.title: A trapped Alice booting Bill the Lizard
dc.abstract: A particularly whimsical illustration that depicts one of Alice's many changes in size in the course of the novel.  Here she has become trapped in the White Rabbit's house and she has kicked Bill the Lizard (sent by the White Rabbit to investigate) out the chimney.

dc.title: Alice and the Queen of Hearts
dc.abstract: This version of Alice,  translated into Arabic, is part of the "Green Library for Children" series.  The illustrator is unknown, but Alices's adventure is depicted in a whimsical and colorful manner.  The cover shows a wide-eyed Alice with brown pigtails, standing with a young Queen of Hearts in a blue dress.

dc.title: Off with their heads!'
dc.abstract: Ratto is an Italian artist whose illustrations, colorful and charming, have graced a number of children's books besides Alice, including The Wild Swans, Jack and the Beanstalk, and the fairy tales of Oscar Wilde.  Here she has depicted a bemused Alice confronting the angry Queen of Hearts, who has just discovered that three of her gardeners are painting a bush of white roses red.
dc.creator: Cinzia Ratto
dc.citation: Lewis Carroll. Alice in Wonderland. Borders Press, 2002

dc.title: Alice standing before the jury for the trial of the Knave of Hearts
dc.abstract: Taylor's various interpretations of Alice are created from Victorian-era photographs, which are then colorized and Photoshopped to fit into the story.  As such, each Alice in this book is different, but still embodies the character.  Here we see Alice and the White Rabbit in court, in front of the lizars and woodland creatures of the jury.
dc.creator: Maggie Taylor
dc.citation: Lewis Carroll. Lewis Carroll's Alice's Adventures in Wonderland. Modernbook Editions, 2008
dc.rights: A copyright review process in August 2018 has determined that this particular illustration is still in copyright, held by the illustrator, Maggie Taylor (©2008), who graciously shared permission for Texas A&M University Libraries to display this image in this online exhibit. dc.title: Jabberwocky
dc.abstract: Drake's watercolor illustration of the Jabberwock features its companion poem from Through the Looking Glass.  The poem is printed in reverse, so it can only be read by viewing it through a looking glass, as Alice did.

dc.title: Queen Alice
dc.abstract: Bachelier is a noted French illustrator and artist who utilizes colorful and flowing, almost dreamlike, imagery for both Alice novels.  This scene is near the end of Through the Looking Glass, in which Alice, having crossed the chessboard of Looking-Glass Land from the Seventh to the Eighth Square, has changed from a pawn to  a queen.  She sits with her fellow monarchs, the Red and White Queens.
dc.creator: Anne Bachelier
dc.citation: Lewis Carroll. Alice's Adventures in Wonderland and Through the Looking Glass and What Alice Found There. CFM Gallery, 2012

dc.title: An overgrown Alice
dc.abstract: Lewis Carroll's original illustrations of Alice are simpler and less expressive than those of Sir John Tenniel, who created the illustrations of Alice widely known today.  She still wears a blue dress, but she has dark brown hhar.  Alice is shown drinking the potion that makes her grow as big as a house.
dc.creator: Lewis Carroll
dc.citation: Lewis Carroll. Alice's Adventures Under Ground. Artist's Choice, 2013
dc.rights: A copyright review process in August 2018 has determined that this particular item is in the public domain since the book in which this illustration originally appeared was published pre-1923.

dc.title: A particularly surreal Tea Party
dc.abstract: Inky Parrot Press is renowned for its beautifully and cleverly illustrated books, as well as its variety of illustrators.  This copy of Alice was illustrated by 27 individuals; this image, depicting Alice at the Mad Tea Party, was made by Robi Dwi Antono

dc.title: Warrior Alice with Jabberwock
dc.abstract: Here Dominguez, a Spanish illustrator of children's books, presents a scene that does not, in fact, appear in the novel.  Alice, depicted as a warrior knight (similar to her portrayal by Mia Wasikowska in Tim Burton's 2010 Alice in Wonderland film), is confronting the Jabberwock, who here appears as something of a hybrid of a dragon and the Xenomorph from the Alien films.
dc.creator: Angel Dominguez
dc.citation: Lewis Carroll. Through the Looking-Glass and What Alice Found There. Inky Parrot Press, 2015

dc.title: Touseled Alice
dc.abstract: This simple rendering of Alice is from famed illustrator, book designer, and printmaker Moser, whose works also include illustrated versions of The Holy Bible, Moby Dick, Dracula, Frankenstin, The Wizard of Oz, and The Adventures of Huckleberry Finn.  Moser's edition of Alice won the 1983 National Book Award for Design and Illustration.
